full_title_en: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Unspecified Functional Bowel Disorder
medium_description_en: Official Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of unspecified functional bowel disorder.
instructions_en:
Use in patients who present with bowel symptoms for at least 6 months for which there is no systemic cause or other functional bowel disorder.

Patients with any of the following features must be evaluated clinically for other diagnoses even though functional constipation may be present:

  • Signs or symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

  • Unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

  • Unintentional weight loss.

  • Palpable abdominal mass or lymphadenopathy on exam.

  • Family history of colon cancer and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Onset of symptoms age ≥50 years and have not had age-appropriate colon cancer screening.

  • Sudden or acute onset of new change in bowel habit.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Use in patients who present with bowel symptoms for which there is no systemic cause and where they do not meet criteria for another functional bowel disorder such as irritable bowel syndrome, functional constipation, functional diarrhea, or functional abdominal bloating/distension.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• It is important to ensure the patient does not have another functional bowel disorder prior to establishing this diagnosis. The use of the irritable bowel syndrome, functional constipation, functional diarrhea, or functional abdominal bloating/distension calculators may be helpful.

  • It is important to follow the patient to see their symptoms evolve to meet a more specific criteria for another disorder of gut brain interaction, e.g. IBS.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Used to diagnose unspecified functional bowel disorder in the absence of secondary causes of bowel symptoms or another functional bowel disorder.

  • Making a diagnosis will help guide the need for further work-up and management.

  • Establishing a diagnosis may be helpful in having a conversation with patients about the role of the gut-brain axis in the development of bowel symptoms.

next_steps.advice_en:
If diagnosis not met (negative):

Symptoms unlikely to be caused by unspecified functional bowel disorder. Consider further assessment as clinically indicated.

If meets diagnosis (positive):

Likely diagnosis of unspecified functional bowel disorder. Consider initiating treatment.
next_steps.management_en: Management should be guided by patient symptoms and severity. To date, there are no studies to support specific treatment in unspecified functional bowel disorders.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: This calculator should only be used in patients where a secondary cause of bowel (e.g. structural cause, systemic illness, medications) is not suspected based on clinical history, physical exam and initial work-up.

about.formula_en:
To fulfill the Rome IV criteria for unspecified functional bowel disorder, patient must have the following (for 3 months prior with symptom onset ≥6 months ago):

  1. Bowel symptoms not attributable to an organic etiology that do not meet criteria for IBS or functional constipation, diarrhea, or abdominal bloating/distention disorders.
about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
The Rome criteria were initially developed as a way to classify and diagnose the various disorders of gut brain interaction such as functional dyspepsia, functional constipation, and irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) based primarily on symptoms. 

The development of the Rome IV questionnaires began with a survey of 1,162 adults without gastrointestinal disorders to determine the frequency in the US general population of various gastrointestinal symptoms. The 90th percentile of symptom frequency was used to define what was considered an abnormal frequency of symptoms.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Lacy BE, Mearin F, Chang L. et al. Bowel disorders. Gastroenterology. 2016;150:1393-1407.

Validation.text: Robin SG, Keller C, Zwiener R, et al. Prevalence of Pediatric Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders Utilizing the Rome IV Criteria. J Pediatr. 2018;195:134-139.

creator_info.about_en: Douglas Drossman, MD, is professor emeritus of medicine and psychiatry at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine. He is founder, President Emeritus and Chief of Operations of the Rome Foundation. He is also the founder of the Drossman Center for the Education and Practice of Biopsychosocial Care and Drossman Consulting, LLC. Dr. Drossman has written over 500 articles and book chapters, has published two books, a GI procedure manual and a textbook of functional GI disorders (Rome I-IV), and serves on six editorial and advisory boards.

Lin Chang, MD is responsible for the oversight and coordination of the Rome IV calculators on MDCalc. She is a Professor of Medicine at the Vatche and Tamar Manoukian Division of Digestive Diseases at UCLA and is a member of the Rome Foundation Board of Directors.

The Rome Foundation is an independent not for profit 501(c) 3 organization that provides support for activities designed to create scientific data and educational information to assist in the diagnosis and treatment of Disorders of Gut-Brain Interaction (DGBI), also known as functional gastrointestinal (GI) disorders. Their mission is to improve the lives of people with DGBI. Over the last 3 decades, the Rome organization has sought to legitimize and update our knowledge of the DGBIs. This has been accomplished by bringing together scientists and clinicians from around the world to classify and critically appraise the science of GI function and dysfunction. This knowledge permits clinical scientists to make recommendations for diagnosis and treatment that can be applied in research and clinical practice. Diagnosis is based on the use of symptom-based criteria which are used in clinical trials and daily practice.
